DIV1.P: AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, IN DRURY - LANE.
LONDON: Printed for T. BECKET, the Corner of the Adelphi, in the Strand. 1775.

THIS little Drama, which had been thrown aside for many years, was brought out last season, with some altera∣tions, for the benefit of Mr. KING, as a token of regard for one, who, during a long engagement, was never known, unless confined by real illness, to disappoint the Public, or distress the Managers—The Author is sincerely apprehensive that the excellence of the performance upon the stage, will greatly lessen its credit with the readers in the closet.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: Written by GEORGE COLMAN. Spoken by Mr. KING.
DIV1.L: FASHION in ev'ry thing bears sov'reign sway,
And words and periwigs have both their day:
Each have their purlieus too, are modish each
In stated districts, wigs as well as speech.
The Tyburn scratch, thick club, and Temple tye,
The parson's feather-top, frizz'd broad and high!
The coachman's cauliflower, built tiers on tiers!
Differ not more from bags and brigadiers,
Than great St. George's, or St. James's stiles,
From the broad dialect of Broad St. Giles.
What is BON TON?—Oh, damme, cries a buck—
Half drunk—ask me, my dear, and you're in luck!
Bon Ton's to swear, break windows, beat the watch,
Pick up a wench, drink healths, and roar a catch.
Keep it up, keep it up! damme, take your swing!
Bon Ton is Life, my boy; Bon Ton's the thing!
Ah! I loves life, and all the joys it yields—
Says Madam Fussock, warm from Spital-fields.
Bone Tone's the space 'twixt Saturday and Monday,
And riding in a one-horse chair o' Sunday!
'Tis drinking tea on summer afternoons
At Bagnigge-Wells, with China and gilt spoons!
'Tis laying by our stuffs, red cloaks, and pattens,
To dance Cow-tillions, all in silks and sattins!
Vulgar! cries Miss. Observe in higher life
The feather'd spinster, and thrice-feather'd wife!
The CLUB'S Bon Ton. Bon Ton's a constant trade.
Of rout, Festino, Ball and Masquerade!
'Tis plays and puppet-shews; 'tis something new!
'Tis losing thousands ev'ry night at lu!
Nature it thwarts, and contradicts all reason;
'Tis stiff French stays, and fruit when out of season!
A rose, when half a guinea is the price;
A set of bays, scarce bigger than six mice;
To visit friends, you never wish to see;
Marriage 'twixt those, who never can agree;
Old dowagers, drest, painted, patch'd, and curl'd;
This is Bon Ton, and this we call the world!
The Lines between Crotchets are omitted at the Theatre.[True, says my Lord; and thou my only son,
Whate'er your faults, ne'er sin against Bon Ton!
Who toils for learning at a publick school,
And digs for Greek and Latin is a fool.
French, French, my boy's the thing! jasez! prate, chatter!
Trim be the mode, whipt-syllabub the matter!
Walk like a Frenchman! for on English pegs
Moves native aukwardness with two left legs.
Of courtly friendship form a treacherous league;
Seduce men's daughters, with their wives intrigue;
In sightly semicircles round your nails;
Keep your teeth clean—and grin, if small talk fails—
But never laugh, whatever jest prevails!
Nothing but nonsense e'er gave laughter birth,
That vulgar way the vulgar shew their mirth.
Laughter's a rude convulsion, sense that justles,
Disturbs the cockles, and distorts the muscles.
Hearts may be black, but all should wear clean faces;
The Graces, boy! the Graces, Graces, Graces!]
Such is Bon Ton! and walk this city thro',
In building, scribbling, fighting, and virtù,
And various other shapes, 'twill rise to view.
To-night our Bayes, with bold, but careless tints,
Hits off a sketch or two, like Darly's prints.
Should connoisseurs allow his rough draughts strike 'em,
'Twill be Bon Ton to see 'em and to like 'em.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady MINIKIN and Miss TITTUP.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: IT is not, my dear, that I have the least regard for my Lord; I had no love for him before I married him, and you know, Matrimony is no breeder of affection; but it hurts my pride, that he should neglect me, and run after other women.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, how can you be so hypocritical, Lady Minikin, as to pretend to uneasiness at such trifles: but pray have you made any new discoveries of my Lord's gallantry?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: New discoveries! why, I saw him myself yesterday morning in a hackney coach, with a minx in a pink car∣dinal; you shall absolutely burn your's, Tittup, for I shall never bear to see one of that colour again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Sure she does not suspect me (aside). And where was your Ladyship, pray, when you saw him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Taking the air with Colonel Tivy in his Vis-a-Vis.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: But, my dear Lady Minikin, how can you be so angry that my Lord was hurting your pride, as you call it, in the hackney-coach, when you had him so much in your power, in the Vis-a-Vis?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: What, with my Lord's friend, and my friend's lover! (takes her by the hand) O fye, Tittup!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Pooh, pooh, Love and Friendship are very fine names to be sure, but they are mere visiting acquaintance; we know their names indeed, talk of 'em sometimes, and let 'em knock at our doors, but we never let 'em in, you know. (looking roguishly at her).

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: I vow, Tittup, you are extremely polite.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: I am extremely indifferent in these affairs, thanks to my education—We must marry, you know, because other people of fashion marry; but I should think very meanly of myself, if after I was married, I should feel the least concern at all about my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: I hate to praise myself, and yet I may with truth aver, that no woman of quality ever had, can have, or will have, so consummate a contempt for her Lord, as I have for my most honourable and puissant Earl of Minikin, Viscount Perriwinkle, and Baron Titmouse—Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: But is it not strange, Lady Minikin, that merely his being your husband, should create such indifference; for certainly, in every other eye, his Lordship has great accomplishments.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Accomplishments! thy head is certainly turn'd; if you know any of 'em, pray let's have 'em; they are a novelty, and will amuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Imprimis, he is a man of quality.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Which, to be sure, includes all the cardinal virtues:—poor girl!—go on!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: He is a very handsome man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: He has a very bad constitution.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: He has wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: He is a Lord, and a little goes a great way,

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: He has great good nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: No wonder—he's a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: And then his fortune, you'll allow—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Was a great one—but he games, and if fairly, he's undone; if not, he deserves to be hang'd—and so, Exit my Lord Minikin—And now, let your wise uncle, and my good cousin Sir John Trotley, Baronet, enter: Where is he, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: In his own room, I suppose, reading pamphlets and news-papers, against the enormities of the times; if he stays here a week longer, notwithstanding my expecta∣tions from him, I shall certainly affront him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: I am a great favourite, but it is impossible much longer to act up to his very righteous ideas of things;—Is'n't it pleasant to hear him abuse every body, and every thing, and yet always finishing with a—You'll excuse me, Cou∣sin?—Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: What do you think the Goth said to me yesterday? one of the knots of his Tye hanging down his left shoulder, and his fring'd cravat nicely twisted down his breast, and thrust thro' his gold button hole, which look'd exactly like my little Barbet's head in his gold collar—Niece Tittup, cries he, drawing himself up, I protest against this manner of conducting yourself, both at home and abroad.—What are your objections, Sir John, an∣swered I, a little pertly.—Various and manifold, reply'd he; I have no time to enumerate particulars now, but I will venture to prophecy, if you keep whirling round in the vortex of Pantheons, Operas, Festinos, Coteries, Masquerades, and all the Devilades in this town, your head will be giddy, down you will fall, lose the name of Lucretia, and be call'd nothing but Tittup ever after—Youll excuse me, cousin!—and so he left me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: O, the barbarian!

SP.SPEAKER: GYMP.
SP.P: A card your Ladyship, from Mrs. Pewitt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MIN.
SP.P: Poor Pewitt!—If she can be but seen at public places, with a woman of quality, she's the happiest of Plebeians.

DIV3.P: “Mrs. Pewitt's respects to Lady Minikin, and Miss Tittup; hopes to have the pleasure of attending them, to Lady Filligree's bali this evening.—Lady Daisey sees masks.”—We'll certainly attend her—Gymp, put some message cards upon my toilet, I'll send an an∣swer immediately; and tell one of my footmen, that he must make some visits for me to-day again, and send me a list of those he made yesterday: he must be sure to call at Lady Pettitoes, and if she shou'd unluckily be at home, he must say that he came to inquire after her sprain'd ancle.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: Ay, ay, give our compliments to her sprain'd ancle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MIN.
SP.P: That woman's so fat, she'll never get well of it, and I am resolv'd not to call at her door myself, till I am sure of not finding her at home.—I am horridly low spirited to∣day, do, send your Colonel to play at chess with me, since he belong'd to you, Titty, I have taken a kind of liking to him; I like every thing that loves my Titty.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: I know you do, my dear Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MIN.
SP.P: That sneer I don't like; if she suspects, I shall hate her: (aside.) Well, dear Titty, I'll go and write my cards, and dress for the masquerade, and if that won't raise my spirits, you must assist me to plague my Lord a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: Yes, and I'll plague my Lady a little, or I am much mistaken: my Lord shall know every tittle that has passed: what a poor, blind, half-witted, self-conceied creature, this dear friend and relation of mine is! and what a fine spirited gallant soldier my Colonel is! my Lady Mini∣kin likes him, he likes my fortune; my Lord likes me, and I like my Lord; however, not so much as he ima∣gines, or to play the fool so rashly as he may expect; she must be very silly indeed, who can't flutter about the flame, without burning her wings—What a great re∣volution in this family, in the space of fifteen months! —we went out of England, a very aukward, regular, good English family! but half a year in France, and a winter passed in the warmer climate of Italy, have ripen'd our minds to every refinement of ease, dissipation and pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: May I hope, Madam, that your humble servant had some share in your last reverie?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: How is it possible to have the least knowledge of Co∣lonel Tivy and not make him the principal object of one's reflections.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: That man must have very little feeling and taste, who is not proud of a place in the thoughts of the finest woman in Europe.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: O fye, Colonel!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. TIVY.
SP.P: By my honour, Madam, I mean what I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: By your honour, Colonel! why will you pass off your counters to me? don't I know that you fine Gentle∣men regard no honour but that which is given at the gam∣ing table; and which indeed ought to be the only ho∣nour you shou'd make free with.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: How can you, Miss, treat me so cruelly? have I not absolutely forsworn dice, mistress, every thing since I dar'd to offer myself to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: Yes, Colonel, and when I dare to receive you, you may return to every thing again, and not violate the laws of the present happy matrimonial establishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: Give me but your consent, Madam, and your life to come—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: Do you get my consent, Colonel, and I'll take care of my life to come.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: How shall I get your consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: By getting me in the humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: But how to get you in the humour?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: O, there are several ways; I am very good natur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: Are you in the humour now?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: Try me.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: How shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: How shall I!—you a soldier, and not know the art military?—how shall I?—I'll tell you how;—when you have a subtle, treacherous, politic enemy to deal with, never stand shilly shally, and lose your time in treaties and parlies, but cock your hat, draw your sword;— march, beat drum—dub, dub, a dub—present, fire, piff-pauff—'tis done! they fly, they yield—Victoria! Victoria!—(Running off.)

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: Stay, stay, my dear, dear Angel!—(Bringing her back.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: No, no, no, I have no time to be kill'd now; be∣sides, Lady Minikin is in the vapours, and wants you at chess, and my Lord, is low spirited, and wants me at picquet; my uncle is in an ill humour and wants me to discard you, and go with him into the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: And will you, Miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: Will I!—no, I never do as I am bid; but you ought —so go to my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: Nay, but Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: Nay, but Colonel, if you won't obey your command∣ing officer, you shall be broke, and then my maid won's accept of you; so march, Colonel!—look'ee, Sir, I will command before marriage, and do what I please after∣wards, or I have been well educated to very little purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P:
What a mad devil it is!—now, if I had the least af∣fection for the girl, I shou'd be damnably vext at
this!—but she has a fine fortune, and I must have her if I can.—Tol, lol, lol, &c.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir JOHN TROTLEY and DAVY.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, Davy, you talk like a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: It is a fine place, your honour, and I cou'd live here for ever!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: More shame for you:—live here for ever!—what, among thieves and pick-pockets!—what a revolution since my time! the more I see, the more I've cause for lamen∣tation; what a dreadful change has time brought about in twenty years! I shou'd not have known the place again, nor the people; all the signs that made so noble an appearance, are all taken down;—not a bob or tye-wig to be seen! all the degrees from the parade in St. James's Park, to the stool and brush at the corner of every street, have their hair tied up—the mason laying bricks, the baker with his basket, the post-boy crying news-papers, and the doctors prescribing physick, have all their hair ty'd up; and that's the reason so many heads are tied up every month.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: I shall have my head tied up to-morrow;—Mr. Wisp will do it for me—your honour and I look like Philistines among 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P:
And I shall break your head if it is tied up; I hate in∣novation;—all confusion and no distinction!—the streets now are as smooth as a turnpike-road? no rattling and exercise in the hackney-coaches; those who ride in 'em are all fast asleep; and they have strings in their hands,
that the coachman must pull to waken 'em, when they are to be set down—what luxury and abomination!

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: Is it so, your honour? 'feckins, I lik'd it hugely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: But you must hate and detest London.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: How can I manage that, your honour, when there is every thing to delight my eye, and cherish my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: 'Tis all deceit and delusion.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: Such crowding, coaching, carting and squeezing, such a power of fine sights, fine shops full of fine things, and then such fine illuminations all of a row! and such fine dainty ladies in the streets, so civil and so grace∣less—they talk of country girls, these here look more healthy and rosy by half.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Sirrah, they are prostitutes, and are civil to delude and destroy you: they are painted Jezabels, and they who hearken to 'em, like Jezabel of old will go to the dogs; if you dare to look at 'em, you will be tainted, and if you speak to 'em you are undone.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: Bless us, bless us!—how does your honour know all this!—were they as bad in your time?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Not by half, Davy—In my time, there was a sort of decency in the worst of women;—but the harlots now watch like tygers for their prey; and drag you to their dens of infamy—see, Davy, how they have torn my neckcloth.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: If you had gone civilly, your honour, they wou'd not have hurt you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Well, we'll get away as fast as we can.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: Not this month, I hope, for I have not had half my belly full yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: I'll knock you down, Davy, if you grow profligate; you shan't go out again to-night, and to-morrow keep in my room, and stay till I can look over my things, and see they don't cheat you.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: Your honour then won't keep your word with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Why, what did I promise you?

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: That I shou'd take sixpen'oth of one of the theatres to-night, and a shilling place at the other to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Well, well, so I did: is it a moral piece, Davy?

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: O yes, and written by a clergyman; it is call'd the Rival Cannanites, or the Tragedy of Braggadocia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
DAVY.
SP.P: To be sure, your honour—as I am to go so soon, I'll make a night of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: This fellow wou'd turn rake and maccaroni if he was to stay here a week longer—bless me, what dangers are in this town at every step! O, that I were once settled safe again at Trotley place!—nothing but to save my country shou'd bring me back again; my niece Lucretia, is so be-fashioned and be-devill'd, that nothing I fear, can save her; however, to ease my conscience, I must try: but what can be expected from the young women of these times, but sallow looks, wild schemes, saucy words, and loose morals!—they lie a-bed all day, sit up all night; if they are silent, they are gaming, and if they talk, 'tis either scandal or infidelity; and that they may look what they are, their heads are all feather, and round their necks are twisted, rattle-snake tippets—O Tempora, O Mores!

DIV3.STAGE: LORD MINIKIN discover'd in his powdering gown, with JESSAMY and MIGNON.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Pry'thee, Mignon, don't plague me any more; dost think that a nobleman's head has nothing to do but be tortur'd all day under thy infernal fingers! give me my cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: MIGNON.
SP.P: Ven you loss your monee, my Lor, you no goot hu∣mour, the devil may ress your cheveu for me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: That fellow's an impudent rascal, but he's a genius, so I must bear with him. Our beef and pudding enriches their blood so much, that the slaves in a month, for∣get their misery and soup-maigre—O, my head!—a chair, Jessamy!—I must absolutely change my wine-mer∣chant: I can't taste his champaigne, without disorder∣ing myself for a week!—heigho!—(sighs).

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: What makes you sigh, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Because you were so near me, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Indeed! I shou'd rather have thought my Lady had been with you—by your looks, my Lord, I am afraid, Fortune jilted you last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: No, faith; our champaigne was not good yesterday, and I am vapour'd like our English November; but one glance of my Tittup can dispel vapours like—like—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Like something very fine to be sure; but pray keep your simile for the next time;—and hark'ee—a little prudence will not be amiss; Mr. Jessamy will think you mad, and me worse.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: O, pray don't mind me, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Gadso, Jessamy, look out my Domino, and I'll ring the bell when I want you.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: I shall, my Lord;—Miss thinks that every body is blind in the house but herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Upon my word, my Lord, you must be a little more prudent, or we shall become the town-talk.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: And so I will, my dear; and therefore to prevent sur∣prize, I'll lock the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: What do you mean, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Prudence, child, prudence; I keep all my jewels under lock and key.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: You are not in possession yet, my Lord: I can't stay two minutes: I only came to tell you that Lady Minikin saw us yesterday in the hackney-coach; she did not know me, I believe; she pretends to be greatly uneasy at your neglect of her; she certainly has some mischief in her head.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: No intentions, I hope, of being fond of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: No, no, make yourself easy; she hates you most un∣alterably.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: You have given me spirits again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Her pride is alarm'd that you should prefer any of the sex to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Her pride then has been alarm'd ever since I had the honour of knowing her.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: But, dear my Lord, let us be merry and wise; should she ever be convinc'd that we have a tendre for each other, she certainly wou'd proclaim it, and then—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: We shou'd be envy'd, and she wou'd be laught at, my sweet cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Nay, I wou'd have her mortify'd too—for tho' I love her Ladyship sincerely, I cannot say, but I love a little mischief as sincerely: but then if my uncle Trotley shou'd know of our affairs, he is so old-fashion'd, prudish, and out of the way, he wou'd either strike me out of his will, or insist upon my quitting the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: My good cousin is a queer mortal, that's certain; I wish we could get him handsomely into the country again—he has a fine fortune to leave behind him—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: But then he lives so regularly, and never makes use of a physician, that he may live these twenty years.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: What can we do with the Barbarian?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: I don't know what's the matter with me, but I am really in fear of him; I suppose, reading his formal books when I was in the country with him, and going so constantly to church, with my elbows stuck to my hips, and my toes turn'd in, has given me these foolish prejudices.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Then you must affront him, or you'll never get the better of him.

DIV3.STAGE: Sir JOHN TROTLEY. (Knocking at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: My Lord, my Lord, are you busy?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Heav'ns! 'tis that detestable brute, my uncle!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: That horrid dog, my cousin!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: What shall we do, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Nay, my Lord, my Lord, I heard you; pray let me speak with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Ho, Sir John, is it you? I beg your pardon, I'll put up my papers and open the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: I'm coming, Sir John! here, here, get behind my great chair; he shan't see you, and you may hear all; I'll be short and pleasant with him.

DIV3.STAGE: (Puts her behind the chair, and opens the door.
(During this Scene, my Lord turns the chair as Sir John moves to conceal Tittup.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: You'll excuse me, my Lord, that I have broken in upon you? I heard you talking pretty loud; what have you no-body with you? what were you about, cousin?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P:
A particular affair, Sir John; I always lock myself up
to study my speeches, and speak 'em aloud for the sake of the tone and action.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Ay, ay, 'tis the best way; I am sorry I disturb'd you; —you'll excuse me, cousin!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: I am rather oblig'd to you, Sir John;—intense appli∣cation to these things, ruins my health; but one must do it for the sake of the nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: May be so, and I hope the nation will be the better for't—you'll excuse me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Excuse you, Sir John, I love your frankness; but why won't you be franker still? we have always something for dinner, and you will never dine at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: You must know, my Lord, that I love to know what I eat;—I hate to travel, where I don't know my way; and since you have brought in foreign fashions and figaries, every thing and every body are in masquerade; your men and manners too are as much fritter'd and fricasi'd, as your beef and mutton; I love a plain dish, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: I wish I was out of the room, or he at the bottom of the Thames.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: But to the point;—I came, my Lord, to open my mind to you about my niece Tittup; shall I do it freely?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Now for it!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: The freer the better; Tittup's a fine girl, cousin, and deserves all the kindness you can shew her.

DIV3.STAGE: (Lord Minikin and Tittup make signs at each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: She must deserve it tho', before she shall have it; and I wou'd have her begin with lengthening her petticoats, covering her shoulders, and wearing a cap upon her head.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: O, frightful!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Don't you think a taper leg, and falling shoulders, and fine hair, delightful objects, Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: And therefore ought to be conceal'd; 'tis their interest to conceal 'em; when you take from the men, the plea∣sure of imagination, there will be a scarcity of husbands; —and then taper legs, falling shoulders and fine hair, may be had for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Well said, Sir John; ha, ha!—your niece shall wear a horseman's-coat, and jack-boots to please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: You may sneer, my Lord, but for all that, I think my niece in a bad way; she must leave me and the country, forsooth, to travel and see good company and fashions; I have seen 'em too, and wish from my heart, that she is not much the worse for her journey:—you'll excuse me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: But why in a passion, Sir John?—

DIV3.STAGE: (My Lord nods and laughs at Miss Tittup, who peeps from behind)
DIV3.P: Don't you think that my lady and I shall be able and willing to put her into the right road?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Zounds! my Lord, you are out of it yourself; this comes of your travelling; all the town knows how you and my lady live together; and I must tell you—you'll excuse me!—that my neice suffers by the bargain; prudence, my Lord, is a very fine thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: So is a long neckcloth nicely twisted into a button∣hole, but I don't chuse to wear one;—you'll excuse me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: I wish that he who first chang'd long neckcloths, for such things as you wear, had the wearing of a twisted neckcloth that I wou'd give him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Pry'thee, Baronet, don't be so horridly out of the way; prudence is a very vulgar virtue, and so incom∣patible with our present ease and refinement, that a prudent man of fashion is now as great a miracle as a pale woman of quality; we got rid of our mauvais honte, at the time that we imported our neighbour's rouge, and their morals.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Did you ever hear the like! I am not surpriz'd, my Lord, that you think so lightly, and talk so vainly, who are so polite a husband; your lady, my cousin, is a fine woman, and brought you a fine fortune, and deserves better usage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Will you have her, Sir John? She is very much at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Profligate!—What did you marry her for, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Convenience!—Marriage is not now-a-days, an affair of inclination, but convenience; and they who marry for love, and such old-fashion'd stuff, are to me as ridi∣culous as those that advertise for an agreeable companion in a post-chaise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: I have done, my Lord; Miss Tittup shall either return with me into the country, or not a penny shall she have from Sir John Trotley, Baronet.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: I am frighten'd out of my wits!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Pray, my Lord, what husband is this you have got for her?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: A friend of mine; a man of wit, and a fine gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: May be so, and yet make a damn'd husband for all that▪ You'll excuse me!—What estate has he, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: He's a Colonel; his elder brother, Sir Tan Tivy, will certainly break his neck, and then my friend will be a happy man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Here's morals!—a happy man when his brother has broke his neck!—a happy man—Mercy on me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Why he'll have six thousand a year, Sir John—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: I don't care what he'll have, nor I don't care what he is, nor who my niece marries; she is a fine lady and let her have a fine gentleman; I shan't hinder her; I'll away into the country to-morrow, and leave you to your fine doings; I have no relish for 'em, not I; I can't live among you, nor eat with you, nor game with you; I hate cards and dice, I will neither rob nor be robb'd; I am contented with what I have, and am very happy, my Lord, though my brother has not broke his neck;—you'll excuse me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! Come, fox, come out of your hole! Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, you have undone me; not a foot shall I have of Trotley Manor, that's positive!—but no matter, there's no danger of his breaking his neck, so I'll e'en make myself happy with what I have, and behave to him, for the future, as if he was a poor relation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN,
SP.STAGE: (kneeling, snatching her hand, and kissing it.)
SP.P: I must kneel and adore you for your spirit; my sweet, heavenly Lucretia!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: One thing I had forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Ha! he's here again!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Why, what the devil;—heigho! my niece Lucretia, and my virtuous Lord, studying speeches for the good of the nation.—Yes, yes, you have been making fine speeches, indeed, my Lord; and your arguments have prevail'd, I see. I beg your pardon, I did not mean to interrupt your studies—you'll excuse me, my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: You'll excuse me, Sir John!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: O yes, my Lord, but I'm afraid the devil won't excuse you at the proper time—Miss Lucretia, how do you, child! You are to be married soon—I wish the gentleman joy, Miss Lucretia; he is a happy man to be sure, and will want nothing but the breaking of his brother's neck to be completely so.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Upon my word, Uncle, you are always putting bad constructions upon things; my Lord has been solliciting me to marry his friend—and having that moment extorted a consent from me—he was thanking and wishing me joy—in his foolish manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Is that all! but how came you here, child?—did you fly down the chimney, or in at the window? for I don't remember seeing you when I was here before.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: How can you talk so, Sir John?—You really confound me with your suspicions;—and then you ask so many ques∣tions, and I have so many things to do, that—that—upon my word, if I don't make haste, I shan't get my dress ready for the ball, so I must run—You'll excuse me, Uncle!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: A fine hopeful young Lady that, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: She's well-bred and has wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: She has wit and breeding enough to laugh at her rela∣tions, and bestow favours on your Lordship; but I must tell you plainly, my Lord—you'll excuse me—that your marrying your Lady, my cousin, to use her ill, and send∣ing for my niece, your cousin, to debauch her—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: You're warm, Sir John, and don't know the world, and I never contend with ignorance and passion; live with me some time, and you'll be satisfied of my honour and good intentions to you and your family; in the mean time command my house;—I must attend immediately Lady Filligree's masquerade, and I am sorry you wont make one with us;—here, Jessamy, give me my do∣mino, and call a chair; and don't let my uncle want for any thing; you'll excuse me, Sir John, tol, lol, derol, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P:
The world's at an end! here's fine work; here are precious doings! this Lord is a pillar of the state too; no wonder that the building is in danger with such rotten supporters;—heigh ho!—and then my poor Lady Mini∣kin, what a friendand husband she is bless'd with!—let me consider!—shou'd I tell the good woman of these pranks, I may only make more mischief, and may hap, go near to kill her, for she's as tender as she's virtuous;—poor Lady! I'll e'en go and comfort her directly, endeavour to draw her from the wickedness of this town into the country, where she shall have reading, fowling, and fishing, to keep up her spirits, and when I die, I will leave her that
part of my fortune, with which I intended to reward the virtues of Miss Lucretia Tittup, with a plague to her!

DIV3.STAGE: Lady MINIKIN and Colonel TIVY discovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Don't urge it, Colonel; I can't think of coming home from the masquerade this evening, tho' I shou'd pass for my niece, it wou'd make an uproar among the servants; and perhaps from the mistake break off your match with Tittup.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: My dear Lady Minikin, you know my marriage with your niece is only a secondary consideration; my first and principal object is you—you, Madam!—therefore, my dear Lady, give me your promise to leave the ball with me; you must, Lady Minikin; a bold young fellow and a sol∣dier as I am, ought not to be kept from plunder when the town has capitulated.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: But it has not capitulated, and perhaps never will; however, Colonel, since you are so furious, I must come to terms, I think—Keep your eyes upon me at the ball, I think I may expect that, and when I drop my handker∣chief, 'tis your signal for pursuing; I shall get home as fast as I can, you may follow me as fast as you can; my Lord and Tittup will be otherwise employ'd; Gymp will let us in the back way—no, no, my heart misgives me!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: Then I am miserable!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
Colonel TIVY. (Seizing it.)
SP.P: Thus I accept your sweet challenge; and if I fail you, may I hereafter, both in love and war, be branded with the name of coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: May I presume, cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Mercy upon us, what are we at now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: How can you be so rude, Sir John, to come into a dy's room, without first knocking at the door? you ave frighten'd me out of my wits!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: I am sure you have frighten'd me out of mine!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: Such rudeness deserves death!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Death indeed! for I shall never recover myself again! pigs of the same stye! all studying for the good of nation!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MIN.
SP.P: We must soothe him, and not provoke him.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: I wou'd cut his throat if you'd permit me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: The Devil has got his hoof into the house, and has corrupted the whole family; I'll get out of it as fast as I can, least he shou'd lay hold of me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Sir John, I must insist upon your not going away in a mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: No mistake, my Lady, I am thoroughly convinced—mercy on me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: I must beg you, Sir John, not to make any wrong constructions upon this accident; you must know, that the moment you was at the door—I had promis'd the Co∣lonel no longer to be his enemy in his designs upon Miss Tittup—this threw him into such a rapture—that upon my promising my interest with you—and wishing him joy— he fell upon his knees, and—and—(laughing) ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! yes, yes, I fell upon my knees, and—and—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Ay, ay, fell upon your knees and—and—Ha! ha! very good joke faith; and the best of it is, that they an wishing joy all over the house upon the same occasion and my Lord is wishing joy, and I wish him joy and you with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P:
Upon my word, Sir John, your cruel suspicions me strongly; and tho' my resentment is curb'd by
regard, my tears cannot be restrain'd; 'tis the only source my innocence has left.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Very fine, truly! and so between the crocodile and the bully, my throat is to be cut; they are guilty of all sort of iniquity, and when they are discover'd, no humility and repentance;—the Ladies have resource to their tongues or their tears, and the gallants to their swords.—That I may not be drawn in by the one, or drawn upon by the other, I'll hurry into the country while I retain my senses, and can sleep in a whole skin.

DIV3.TRAILER: The END of the FIRST ACT.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT II. SCENE I.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: THERE is no bearing this! what a land are we in! upon my word, Mr. Jessamy, you should look well to the house, there are certainly rogues about it: for I did but cross the way just now to the Pamphlet-shop, to buy a touch of the times, and they have taken my hanger from my side; ay, and had a pluck at my watch too, but I heard of their tricks, and had it sew'd to my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: Don't be alarm'd, Sir John; 'tis a very common thing, and if you will walk the streets without convoy, you will be pick'd up by privateers of all kinds; ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Not be alarm'd when I am robb'd!—why, they might have cut my throat with my own hanger; I shan't sleep a wink all night; so pray lend me some weapon of defence, for I am sure if they attack me in the open street, they'll be with me at night again.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: I'll lend you my own sword, Sir John; but be assur'd there's no danger; there's robbing and murder cry'd every night under my window; but it no more dis∣turbs me, than the ticking of my watch at my bed's-head.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Well, well, be that as it will, I must be upon my guard; what a dreadful place this is! but 'tis all owing to the corruption of the times; the great folks game, and the poor folks rob; no wonder that murder ensues; sad, sad, sad!—well, let me but get over this night, and I'll leave this den of thieves to-morrow; how long will your Lord and Lady stay at this masking and mummery before they come home?

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible to say the time, Sir; that merely depends upon the spirits of the company and the nature of the entertainment: for my own part, I generally make it myself till four or five in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Why, what the devil do you make one at these mas∣queradings?

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: I seldom miss, Sir; I may venture to say that nobody knows the trim and small talk of the place better than I do; I was always reckon'd an incomparable mask.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Thou art an incomparable coxcomb, I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: An odd, ridiculous accident happen'd to me at a mas∣querade three years ago; I was in tip-top spirits, and had drank a little too freely of the Champaigne, I be∣lieve.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: You'll be hang'd, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: Wit flew about, in short. I was in spirits; at last, from drinking and rattling, to vary the pleasure, we went to dancing: and who do you think I danc'd a minuet with? he! he! pray guess, Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Danc'd a minuet with.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: My own Lady, that's all; the eyes of the whole as∣sembly were upon us; my Lady dances well, and I be∣lieve, I am pretty tolerable: after the dance, I was running into a little coquetry, and small talk with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: With your Lady?—Chaos is come again!

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: With my Lady—but upon my turning my hand thus—(Conceitedly) egad, she caught me; whisper'd me who I was; I wou'd fain have laugh'd her out of it, but it wou'd not do;—no, no Jessamy, says she, I am not to be deceiv'd: pray wear gloves for the future; for you may as well go bare-fac'd, as shew that hand and diamond ring.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: What a sink of iniquity!—Prostitution on all sides! from the Lord to the pick-pocket: (aside.) Pray, Mr. Jessamy, among your other virtues, I suppose you game a little, eh, Mr. Jessamy?

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: A little whist or so;—but I am ty'd up from the dice; I must never touch a box again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: I wish you was ty'd up somewhere else; I sweat from top to toe! (aside) Pray lend me your sword, Mr. Jessamy; I shall go to my room; and let my Lord and Lady, and my neice Tittup know, that I beg they will excuse ce∣remonies, that I must be up and gone before they go to bed; and that I have a most profound respect and love for them, and—that I hope we shall never see one another again as long as we live.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: I shall certainly obey your commands; what poor ignorant wretches, these country gentlemen are?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: If I stay in this place another day, it wou'd throw me into a fever! Oh I wish it was morning—this comes of visiting my relations!
So, you wicked wretch you—where have you been, and what have you been doing?

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: Merry-making, your honour—London for ever!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Did not I order you to come directly from the play, and not be idling and raking about?

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: Servants don't do what they are bid in London.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: And did not I order you not to make a jackanapes of yourself, and tye your hair up like a monkey?—

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: And therefore I did it—no pleasing the Ladies with∣out this—my Lord's servants call you an old out-of-fa∣shion'd Codger, and have taught me what's what.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Here's an imp of the devil!—he is undone, and will poison the whole country—Sirrah, get every thing ready, I'll be going directly.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: To bed, Sir!—I want to go to bed myself, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Why how now—you are drunk too, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: I am a little, your honour, because I have been drink∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: That is not all—you have been in bad company, Sirrah!

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: Indeed, your honour's mistaken, I never kept such good company in all my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: The fellow does not understand me—where have you been, you drunkard?

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P:
Drinking, to be sure, if I am a drunkard; and if you
had been drinking too, as I have been, you wou'd not be in such a passion with a-body—it makes one so good-na∣tur'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: This is another addition to my misfortunes! I shall have this fellow carry into the country as many vices as will corrupt the whole parish.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: I'll take what I can, to be sure, your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Get away, you beast you, and sleep off the debauchery you have contracted this fortnight, or I shall leave you behind, as a proper person to make one of his Lordship's family.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: So much the better—give me more wages, less work, and the key of the ale-cellar, and I am your servant, if not provide yourself with another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Here's a reprobate!—this is the completion of my mis∣sery!—but harkee Villain—go to bed—and sleep off your iniquity, and then pack up the things, or I'll pack you off to Newgate, and transport you for life.

SP.SPEAKER: DAVY.
SP.P: That for you old Codger (snaps his fingers)—I know the law better than to be frighten'd with moon-shine! I wish that I was to live here all my days!—this is life indeed! a Servant lives up to his eyes in clover; they have wages, and board wages, and nothing to do, but to grow fat and saucy—they are as happy as their master, they play for ever at cards, swear like Emperors, drink like fishes, and go a enching with as much ease, and tranquility, as if they were going to a sermon! Oh! 'tis a fine life!

DIV3.STAGE: SCENE. A Chamber in Lord MINI∣KIN'S House.
Enter Lord MINIKIN, and Miss TITTUP, in Masquerade dresses, lighted by JESSAMY.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Set down the candles, Jessamy, and shou'd your Lady come home let me know—be sure you are not out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: I have liv'd too long with your Lordship, to need the caution—who the Devil have we got now? but that's my Lord's business, and not mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP,
SP.P: Upon my word, my Lord, this coming home so soon from the masquerade is very imprudent, and will cer∣tainly be observ'd—I am most inconceiveably frighten'd I can assure you—my Uncle Trotley has a light in his room; the accident this morning will certainly keep him upon the watch—pray, my Lord, let us defer our meetings 'till he goes into the country—I find that my English heart, tho' it has ventur'd so far, grows fearful, and aukward to practise the freedoms of warmer cli∣mates—(my Lord takes her by the hand) If you will not de∣sist, my Lord—we are separated for ever—the sight of the precipice turns my head, I have been giddy with it too long, and must turn from it while I can—pray be quiet, my Lord, I will meet you to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P:
To-morrow! 'tis an age in my situation—let the weak, bashful, coyish whiner be intimidated with these faint alarms, but let the bold experienced lover kindle
at the danger, and like the Eagle in the mid'st of storms thus pounce upon his prey.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Dear, Mr. Eagle, be merciful, pray let the poor Pid∣geon fly for this once.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: If I do my Dove, may I be curs'd to have my wife as fond of me, as I am now of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY, (without knocking at the door.
SP.P: My Lord, my Lord!—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY,
SP.P: 'Tis I, my Lord, may I come in?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Damn the fellow! What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: Nay, not much my Lord—only my Lady's come home.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: Then I'm undone—what shall I do?—I'll run into my own room.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Then she may meet you going to her's.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: There's a dark, deep closet, my Lord—Miss may hide herself there.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP.
SP.P: For heaven's sake put me into it, and when her La∣dyship's safe, let me know my Lord—What an escape have I had!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: The moment her evil spirit is laid, I'll let my angel out (puts her into the closet.) lock the door on the inside— Come softly to my room, Jessamy—

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: If a board creaks, your Lordship shall never give me a lac'd waistcoat again.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter GYMP lighting in Lady MINIKIN, and Colonel TIVY, in Masquerade dresses.

SP.SPEAKER: GYMP.
SP.P: Pray, my Lady, go no farther with the Colonel, I know you mean nothing but innocence, but I'm sure there will be blood shed, for my Lord is certainly in the house— I'll take my Affadavy that I heard—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. TIVY.
SP.P: It can't be I tell you; we left him this moment at the masquerade—I spoke to him before I came out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: He's too busy and too well employ'd to think of home—but don't tremble so, Gymp. There is no harm I assure you—the Colonel is to marry my Niece, and it is proper to settle some matters relating to it—they are left to us.

SP.SPEAKER: GYMP.
SP.P: Yes, yes, madam, to be sure it is proper that you talk together,—I know you mean nothing but inno∣cence— but indeed there will be blood-shed.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. TIVY.
SP.P: The Girl's a fool. I have no sword by my side.

SP.SPEAKER: GYMP.
SP.P: But my Lord has, and you may kill one another with that—I know you mean nothing but innocence, but I certainly heard him go up the back-stairs into his room talking with Jessamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible but the girl must have fancy'd this— Can't you ask Whisp, or Mignon, if their master is come in?

SP.SPEAKER: GYMP.
SP.P: Lord, my Lady, they are always drunk before this, and asleep in the kitchen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: This frighten'd fool has made me as ridiculous as herself; hark!—Colonel, I'll swear there is something upon the stairs; now I am in the field I find I am a Coward.

SP.SPEAKER: GYMP.
SP.P: There will certainly be blood-shed.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. TIVY.
SP.P: I'll slip down with Gymp this back way then.

SP.SPEAKER: GYMP.
SP.P: O dear my Lady, there is somebody coming up them too.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. TIVY.
SP.P: Zounds! I've got between two fires!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Run into the closet.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. TIVY.
SP.P: There's no retreat—the door is lock'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Behind the chimney-board, Gymp.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. TIVY.
SP.P: I shall certainly be taken prisoner (goes behind the board) you'll let me know when the enemy's decamp'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Leave that to me—do you, Gymp, go down the back-stairs, and leave me to face my Lord, I think I can match him at hypocrisy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: What is your Ladyship so soon return'd from Lady Fillagree's?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: I am sure, my Lord I ought to be more surpriz'd at your being here so soon when I saw you so well enter∣tain'd in a tete-a-tete with a Lady in crimson—such sights my Lord, will always drive me from my most fa∣vourite amusements.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: You find at least, that the Lady, whoever she was, cou'd not engage me to stay, when I found your Lady∣ship had left the ball.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Your Lordship's sneering upon my unhappy temper, may be a proof of your wit, but is none of your hu∣manity, and this behaviour is as great an insult upon me, as even your falsehood itself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Nay, my dear Lady Minikin; if you arr resolv'd to play tragedy, I shall roar away too, and pull out my mbrick handkerchief.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: I think, my Lord, we had better retire to our apartments; my weakness, and your brutality will only expose us to our servants—where is Tittup, pray?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: I left her with the Colonel—a masquerade to young folks, upon the point of matrimony, is as delighful as it is disgusting to those who are happily married, and are wise enough to love home, and the company of their wives.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: False man!—I had as lieve a toad touch'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: She gives me the frisonne—I must propose to stay, or I shall never get rid of her (aside.)—I am quite aguish to∣night, —he—he—do my dear, let us make a little fire here, and have a family tete-a-tete, by way of novelty.

SP.SPEAKER: Enter JESSAMY.
SP.P: Let em take away that chimney-board, and light a fire here immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: What shall I do? (aside.)—Here, Jessamy, there is no occasion—I am going to my own chamber, and my Lord won't stay here by himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: How cruel it is, Lady Minikin, to deprive me of the pleasure of a domestic duetto—a good escape, faith!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: I have too much regard for Lord Minikin, to agree to any thing that would afford him so little pleasure—I shall retire to my own apartments.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Well, if your Ladyship will be cruel, I must still, like the miser, starve and sigh, tho' possessed of the greatest treasure.—(bows) I wish your Ladyship a good night—

DIV3.STAGE: (He takes one candle, and Lady Minikin the other.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MINIKIN.
SP.P: Your Lordship is too obliging—nasty man!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Disagreeable woman!

DIV3.STAGE: (They wipe their lips, and exeunt ceremoniously.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP. (peeping out of the closet.)
SP.P: All's silent now, and quite dark; what has been doing here I cannot guess—I long to be reliev'd, I wish my Lord was come—but I hear a noise!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: I wonder my Lady does not come—I would not have Miss Tittup know of this—'twou'd be ten thousand pounds out of my way, and I can't afford to give so much for a little gallantry.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP. (comes forward.)
SP.P: What would my Colonel say to find his bride, that is to be, in this critical situation.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord MINIKIN, at one door in the dark.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Now to relieve my prisoner.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady MINIKIN, at the other door.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MIN.
SP.P: My poor Colonel will be as miserable, as if he were besieg'd in garrison, I must release him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Hist—hist!—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITTUP, Lady MINIKIN, and Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: Here! here!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: This way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MIN.
SP.P: Softly.

DIV3.STAGE: (They all grope about till Lord Minikin has got Lady Minikin, and the Colonel Miss Tittup.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN. (speaks without.)
SP.P: Light this way, I say; I am sure there are thieves, get a blunderbuss.

SP.SPEAKER: JESSAMY.
SP.P: Indeed you dreamt it, there is nobody but the family.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir JOHN, in his cap, and hanger drawn, with JESSAMY.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Give me the candle, I'll ferret 'em out I warrant, bring a blunderbuss, I say; they have been skipping about that gallery in the dark this half hour; there must be mischief—I have watch'd 'em into this room—ho, ho, are you there?—if you stir, you are dead men—(they retire)—and (seeing the ladies) women too!—egad—ha! what's this? the same party again! and two couple they are of as choice mortals as ever were hatch'd in this righteous town—you'll excuse me, cousins!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: In the name of wonder, how comes all this about?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Well, but hark'ee, my dear cousins, have you not got wrong partners?—here has been some mistake in the dark; I am mighty glad that I have brought you a candle, to set all to rights again—you'll excuse me, gentlemen and ladies!

SP.SPEAKER: GYMP.
SP.P: What in the name of mercy, is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. JOHN.
SP.P: Why the old matter, and the old game, Mrs. Gymp, and I'll match my cousins here at it, against all the world, and I say done first.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: What is the meaning, Sir John, of all this tumult and consternation? may not Lady Minikin and I, and the Colonel and your niece, be seen in my house together without your raising the family, and making this uproar and confusion?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Come, come, good folks, I see you are all confounded, I'll settle this matter in a moment—as for you Colonel—tho' you have not deserv'd plain dealing from me, I will now be serious—you imagine this young lady has an independent fortune, besides expectations from me—'tis a mistake, she has no expectations from me; if she marry you, and I don't consent to her marriage, she will have no fortune at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel TIVY.
SP.P: Plain dealing is a jewel, and to shew you, Sir John, that I can pay you in kind, I am most sincerely oblig'd to you for your intelligence, and I am, ladies, your most obedient humble servant—I shall see you, my Lord, at the club to-morrow?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Sans doute mon cher Colonel—I'll meet you there without fail.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: My Lord, you'll have something else to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: Indeed! what is that, good Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: You must meet your lawyers and creditors to-morrow, and be told, what you have always turn'd a deaf ear to, that the dissipation of your fortune and morals, must be followed by years of parsimony and repentance—as you are fond of going abroad you may indulge that inclination without having it in your power to indulge any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: The bumkin is no fool, and is damn'd satirical—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: This kind of quarantine for pestilential minds, will bring you to your senses, and make you renounce foreign vices and follies, and return with joy to your country and pro∣perty again—read that, my Lord, and know your fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: What an abomination this is! that a man of fashion, and a nobleman, shall be oblig'd to submit to the laws of his country.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Thank heaven, my Lord, we are in that country!— You are silent, ladies—if repentance has subdu'd your tongues, I shall have hopes of you—a little country air might perhaps do well—as you are distress'd, I am at your service—what say you, my Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady MIN.
SP.P: However appearances have condemn'd me, give me leave to disavow the substance of those appearances: My mind has been tainted; but not profligate—your kindness and example may restore me to my former natural English constitution.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Will you resign your Lady to me, my Lord for a time?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord MINIKIN.
SP.P: For ever, dear Sir John, without a murmur.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Well, Miss, and what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: Guilty, uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Guilty! the devil you are? of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss TITT.
SP.P: Of consenting to marry one, whom my heart could not approve, and coquetting with another which friendship, duty, honour, morals, and every thing, but fashion, ought to have forbidden.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN.
SP.P: Thus then, with the wife of one under this arm, and the mistress of another, under this, I sally forth a Knight Errant, to rescue distress'd damsels from those monsters, foreign vices, and Bon Ton, as they call it; and I trust that every English hand and heart here, will assist me in so desperate an undertaking—You'll excuse me, Sirs!
